title: Smooth Scroll - Comprehensive Usage Examples
description: Complete example configurations for page-level smooth scrolling with customizable easing, speed, and behavior patterns

examples.name: Default Smooth Scroll (Balanced Experience)
examples.description: Standard smooth scroll settings for general websites
examples.visualDescription: Medium-paced smooth scrolling with cubic easing, 2.5s animation, normalized wheel events for consistent cross-browser experience
examples.useCase: Corporate websites, blogs, general business sites, content-heavy pages, standard landing pages
notes: aniTime: 2500ms = 2.5 seconds for smooth, balanced animation
stepSize: 500px = moderate scroll distance per wheel event
ease-out-cubic = starts fast, slows down at end (natural feel)
normalizeWheel: true = consistent behavior across Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge
Works well for 90% of websites without customization

examples.name: Fast Responsive Scroll (Quick Navigation)
examples.description: Faster smooth scroll for responsive, snappy user experience
examples.visualDescription: Quick 1-second scrolling with quadratic easing, larger 800px steps, navigation link smoothing enabled
examples.useCase: E-commerce sites, dashboards, web apps, sites with impatient users, mobile-first designs, one-page navigation
notes: aniTime: 1000ms = 1 second for quick, responsive feel
stepSize: 800px = larger jumps reduce scroll fatigue
ease-out-quad = lighter easing, faster completion
smNav: true = enables smooth scrolling for anchor links (#section)
tMult: 2.5 = higher touchpad sensitivity for laptop users
Recommended for sites where users need to find information quickly

examples.name: Cinematic Slow Scroll (Premium Portfolio)
examples.description: Dramatic slow scrolling for immersive, storytelling experiences
examples.visualDescription: Luxurious 4-second scrolling with quintic easing, small 300px steps, premium smooth feel
examples.useCase: Creative portfolios, luxury brands, photography showcases, storytelling sites, product launches, immersive experiences
notes: aniTime: 4000ms = 4 seconds for cinematic, deliberate pacing
stepSize: 300px = small increments create floating sensation
ease-in-out-quint = strongest easing (slow start, slow end, smooth middle)
tMult: 1.2 = reduced touchpad sensitivity prevents jumpy feel
Creates 'floating' effect popular in high-end design
May frustrate users seeking quick information - use sparingly

examples.name: Navigation Link Smoothing (Anchor Scroll)
examples.description: Smooth scroll specifically for anchor link navigation
examples.visualDescription: Medium-speed 2s scrolling with navigation smoothing, perfect for one-page websites with section jumps
examples.useCase: One-page websites, landing pages with sections (#about, #services, #contact), table of contents navigation, marketing pages
notes: smNav: true = critical for anchor link smoothing (e.g., <a href='#services'>)
aniTime: 2000ms = 2 seconds appropriate for section jumps
ease-in-out-cubic = smooth start and end for section transitions
Works with tp-scroll-navigation and tp-table-content blocks
Prevents jarring instant jumps when clicking anchor links
Browser back button still works normally

examples.name: Touchpad Optimized (Laptop Users)
examples.description: High touchpad sensitivity for laptop/trackpad users
examples.visualDescription: Moderate 1.8s scrolling with 3.5x touchpad multiplier, optimized for MacBook/laptop trackpads
examples.useCase: Sites with primarily laptop users, SaaS apps, developer tools, educational platforms, business software
notes: tMult: 3.5 = touchpad movements feel more responsive
Touchpads typically have finer granularity than mouse wheels
normalizeWheel: true = essential for cross-device consistency
Default tMult: 2 often feels sluggish on MacBook trackpads
Test on actual laptops - touchpad behavior varies by OS/hardware
Higher tMult values (4-5) risk feeling too sensitive

examples.name: Infinite Scroll Loop (Experimental)
examples.description: Infinite looping scroll for experimental single-page designs
examples.visualDescription: Continuous looping scroll with 3s animation, quartic easing, wraps from bottom to top seamlessly
examples.useCase: Experimental portfolios, circular narratives, infinite galleries, artistic installations, unconventional designs
notes: infinite: true = when reaching bottom, loops back to top (and vice versa)
Creates continuous scroll illusion for single-page sites
Content must be designed to flow seamlessly top-to-bottom
Can disorient users - provide visual cues (progress indicators)
Not recommended for e-commerce or informational sites
Works best with vertically symmetrical layouts
May conflict with sticky headers/footers - test thoroughly

examples.name: Custom Viewport Scroll (Container Scroll)
examples.description: Smooth scroll within specific viewport/container instead of full page
examples.visualDescription: Smooth scrolling limited to .content-area container, 2.2s animation, useful for complex layouts
examples.useCase: Split-screen layouts, sidebar navigation sites, dashboard apps, sites with fixed headers/sidebars, scrollable content areas
notes: viewport: '.content-area' = CSS selector for scroll container
Allows smooth scroll in specific div instead of whole page
Container must have CSS: overflow-y: auto or scroll
Requires height constraint on viewport element
Useful when header/sidebar should remain fixed while content scrolls
Example CSS: .content-area { height: 100vh; overflow-y: auto; }
Test with multiple viewports - only first match is used

examples.name: Linear Precision Scroll (No Easing)
examples.description: Constant-speed scrolling without easing for precise control
examples.visualDescription: Linear scrolling at constant 1.5s speed, no acceleration/deceleration, perfect for data-heavy interfaces
examples.useCase: Data tables, spreadsheets, code editors, technical documentation, scientific visualizations, precision-required interfaces
notes: easing: 'linear' = constant speed from start to finish, no acceleration
Predictable scrolling for users who need precise positioning
Less 'smooth' feeling but more controllable
Preferred by power users and technical audiences
Good for content where users need to scan methodically (tables, code)
Reduces motion sickness in some users sensitive to easing
Faster aniTime (1500ms) compensates for lack of natural feel

default_smooth.description: Standard smooth scroll for most websites

fast_navigation.description: Quick scrolling with navigation link support

aniTime.description: Animation duration - too short (<500ms) feels jarring, too long (>6000ms) frustrates users

stepSize.description: Scroll step size per wheel event - larger values = faster scrolling

tMult.description: Touchpad scroll multiplier - higher values increase touchpad sensitivity

normalizeWheel.description: Normalize wheel events across browsers - always recommended

easing.description: Easing function - ease-out feels most natural, ease-in-out for cinematic, linear for precision

infinite.description: Enable infinite scroll loop - experimental, use with caution

smNav.description: Enable smooth scroll for navigation anchor links - essential for one-page sites

viewport.description: CSS selector for custom scroll viewport (e.g., '.content-area') - limits smooth scroll to specific container

warnings: ONLY ONE tp-smooth-scroll block per page - multiple instances will conflict
Applies to ENTIRE PAGE by default - cannot selectively disable for sections (unless using custom viewport)
May conflict with other scroll-based animations (parallax, scroll-triggered animations) - test thoroughly
infinite: true is experimental and can disorient users - use sparingly
Very slow aniTime (>4000ms) frustrates users trying to scroll quickly - provide disable option
normalizeWheel: false can cause inconsistent behavior across browsers - keep true unless specific reason
Custom viewport requires container with overflow-y: auto/scroll and height constraint
Touchpad behavior varies greatly across OS (macOS, Windows, Linux) - test on actual devices
Some users prefer standard browser scrolling - consider providing disable option in footer
Mobile devices ignore smooth scroll settings (native momentum scrolling) - this is page-level only
commonMistakes: Adding multiple tp-smooth-scroll blocks - only use once per page
Setting aniTime too high (>5000ms) - users will feel trapped in slow scrolling
Using infinite: true without content designed for looping - creates jarring transitions
Forgetting smNav: true on one-page sites - anchor links will jump instantly
Setting tMult too high (>5) - touchpad becomes hypersensitive and uncontrollable
Not testing on different browsers/devices - wheel event behavior varies
Using custom viewport without proper CSS setup (overflow, height)
Combining with parallax effects without testing - can create motion sickness
Not providing accessibility option to disable - some users get motion sick
Using ease-in easing (slow start, fast end) - feels unnatural for scrolling
bestPractices: Start with default settings (aniTime: 2500, ease-out-cubic) and adjust only if needed
Enable smNav: true for all one-page websites with anchor navigation
Test on real laptops with trackpads - adjust tMult based on user feedback
Provide visual feedback during scroll (progress bar, section indicators)
Add accessibility option to disable smooth scroll (motion sickness consideration)
Use faster settings (aniTime: 1000-1500) for e-commerce and information-heavy sites
Use slower settings (aniTime: 3000-4000) only for portfolios and storytelling sites
Keep normalizeWheel: true for cross-browser consistency
Test with keyboard navigation (Page Up/Down, Space, Arrow keys) - should still work
Avoid infinite: true unless content is specifically designed for looping
For custom viewport, ensure container has fixed height and visible overflow
Use ease-out-* easing for most natural feel (fast start, slow end)
Document smooth scroll settings for client - they may want to adjust over time
Consider user preferences: prefers-reduced-motion media query to disable
Test with mouse wheel, trackpad, and keyboard - all should feel smooth
accessibilityNotes: Respect prefers-reduced-motion CSS media query - disable smooth scroll for users who request reduced motion
Keyboard navigation (Page Up/Down, Space, Home/End) should still work with smooth scroll
Screen reader users typically use keyboard, not mouse - ensure keyboard scrolling feels natural
Smooth scroll can cause motion sickness in some users - provide disable toggle in footer
Very slow scrolling (>3500ms) can disorient users with vestibular disorders
Ensure focus indicators remain visible during smooth scroll animations
Skip-to-content links should bypass smooth scroll for immediate jump (or use short aniTime)
Infinite scroll loops can confuse screen reader users - provide clear navigation landmarks
Test with screen magnification tools - smooth scroll may need faster speeds for zoomed users
Document smooth scroll feature in accessibility statement
Provide keyboard shortcut to toggle smooth scroll on/off (e.g., Ctrl+Shift+S)
Ensure smooth scroll doesn't interfere with browser's native find-on-page (Ctrl+F) scrolling
performanceConsiderations: Smooth scroll uses requestAnimationFrame - minimal CPU impact on modern browsers
Long aniTime (>3000ms) means more animation frames - slight performance cost on low-end devices
normalizeWheel adds event listener overhead - negligible on modern browsers
Infinite scroll requires content height calculation - may slow down on very long pages (10,000+ pixels)
Custom viewport with multiple containers not supported - uses first matched element only
Smooth scroll JavaScript ~5KB minified - loaded only when block is active
Works smoothly up to 20,000px page height without performance issues
Mobile devices ignore smooth scroll (native momentum) - no mobile performance impact
